text: Too kind my old friend, Lee. Tomorrow morning I have a lengthy column on @realmoney.. "When Short Selling Is Done Right" I think it is a good educational post.

Been shorting $TSLA for weeks on a scale higher. My cost basis for the short is about $740/share - so still have a small loss. No biggy, but better than few weeks ago! As the wise man once said.. "we shall see."

No. Bitcoin appreciation is a non recurring event - and, as such, like the sale of a factory, is worth less than $1/share.
You can't make this shit up.

And that's BEFORE taxes. Markets value nonrecurring gains like $TSLA has achieved at a discount to the profit. So after market's valuing and taxes - the $1 billion bitcoin gain is probably worth only $0.50/share. @SquawkCNBC @andrewrsorkin @beckyquick

@SquawkCNBC @andrewrsorkin @beckyquick Bitcoin doesnt move the needle at $TSLA. There are one billion shares outstanding, $850 billion market cap. $1 billion profit in bitcoin is less than $1/share. Enough with the hyperbole Dan...
I am short $RIOT as well as a number of other secondary and tertiary crypto gewgaws.

@beckyquick @andrewrsorkin @SquawkCNBC Typically the value of balance sheet cash or the profits (per share) from non recurring sales (like $TSLA profits on bitcoin) are discounted in the marketplace. +$1 bill crypto gain (by $TSLA) seems like alot but it represents only $1/share
And the value of even that $1/share add needs to be discounted as it is not recurring. $TSLA has 1 billion shares outstanding and a market cap of $800 billion. @threadreaderapp unroll
